		  credit against tax for qualified elementary and secondary education
		  tuition.

Qualified

text.#text:
In the case of an individual, there shall be allowed as a
				credit against the tax imposed by this chapter for the taxable year an amount
				equal to the amount of qualified contributions made by the taxpayer during the
				taxable year.

text.#text:
The
				term

An organization meets the
				requirements of this section if—

such organization
				does not provide grants to eligible students for any expenses other than
				qualified elementary and secondary education expenses,

such organization
				provides grants to—

more than 1
				student, and

different students
				attending more than 1 school,

such organization
				does not earmark or set aside contributions for scholarships on behalf of any
				particular student or to any specific school or group of schools,

such organization
				takes appropriate steps to verify the annual household income and family size
				of eligible students to which it provides grants,

such organization

The reports described in this subsection include—

a report to the
				parents on the student’s academic achievement, including a comparison with the
				aggregate academic achievement of other students in the same grade or level at
				the school who receive a scholarship from a scholarship granting organization,
				if available, and

a report, to each
				scholarship granting organization that provides scholarships to students at the
				school, that includes—

the test results,
				in the aggregate and disaggregated by race or ethnicity and grade level, of the
				students receiving such scholarships who are in grades 3 through 12 on a
				grade-appropriate nationally norm-referenced standardized test, or a
				grade-appropriate State-recognized assessment, and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the Institute of Education Sciences

This

				year.

header.#text:
Excise tax on
			 failure of scholarship granting organizations To make distributions

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is

external-xref.#tail: of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986

header.#text:
Tax on failure
				to distribute receipts

text.#text:
There is hereby imposed a tax on the failure of a
				scholarship granting organization (as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall be equal to 15
				percent of the excess (if any) of—

text.#text: The tax imposed by

the required
				distribution amount with respect to the taxable year, over

the amount of
				receipts of the scholarship granting organization for such taxable year which
				are distributed before the distribution deadline with respect to such
				receipts.

For
				purposes of this section—

The required distribution amount with respect
				to a taxable year is the amount equal to 90 percent of the total receipts of
				the scholarship granting organization for such taxable year.

term.#tail:
includes amounts which are formally committed
				but not distributed.

text.#text:
The
				term

The distribution deadline with respect to receipts for a
				taxable year is the first day of the second taxable year following the taxable
				year in which such receipts are received by the scholarship granting
				organization.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall not apply with
				respect to any failure to make required distributions before the distribution
				deadline which is not willful and is due to reasonable
				cause.
